Genre: Fighting

Publisher: H2 Interactive

• Sound: 9/10
• Music: 9/10

[u]Pros[/u]
+Arcade Mode and Story Mode have their own storyline and progression
+Story Mode has multiple paths depending on which choice you choose which leads to different endings
+Story mode much more longer and detailed than the previous game

+A lot of new game modes which improve length and replay value
+Well drawn character sprites and the stages are well made in design
+Great OST that meshes well with the characters
+Online MP added

[u]Cons[/u]
-Lack of Steam cloud save file support, only saves leaderboard stats

38065496.review:
BlazBlue: Continuum Shift es la segunda entrega de la saga de BlazBlue, continuación directa a Calamity Trigger, en este caso particular hablamos de la versión extended del juego, puesto que Continuum Shift tiene 3 variantes: Continun Shift, Continuum Shift II y Continuum Shift Extended (esta última solo disponible en Japón) siendo la segunda una variante con 3 personajes extra, y la última teniendo 4 personajes y varias adiciones al modo Historia, Pero con este lanzamiento en Steam, ya todo el globo puede disfrutar de la experiencia completa.
BlazBlue: Continuum Shift Extended aparte de retener elementos de su primera entrega incorpora cosas nuevas también las cuales hacen sentir a esta entrega como una buena secuela. En principio hay que agregar que el juego se siente bastante similar a su antecesor, hasta cierto punto, tan similar que parece un DLC de Calamity Trigger, pero esto no es malo, ya que añade bastante al juego anterior, tanto en contenido como valor de rejugabilidad.

[h1]PRESENTACIÓN[/h1]
Al igual que su antecesor, BlazBlue tiene una presentación visual impecable, este juego se lanzó originalmente en 2011 y su apartado gráfico no deja de ser bueno, se ve pulido, se ve limpio y bien trabajado, la Interfaz es técnicamente igual a su antecesor, al menos en estética. La banda sonora es la misma del juego anterior, pero tiene varias pistas adicionales compuestas para esta entrega, la música es espectacular, y cada pista refleja perfectamente la personalidad de cada personaje; a pesar de tener bastante contenido reciclado en ese ámbito tiene suficiente nuevo material para no darse de obsoleto.

[h1]JUGABILIDAD[/h1]
La jugabilidad del juego se mantiene intacta, es exactamente igual a la de su antecesor, hay unos pequeños cambios pero todo se siente relativamente igual, a pesar de esto en Calamity Trigger (Quizás al ser solo un producto de prueba) no se te da un tutorial de como jugar el juego, y básicamente tienes que aprender todo por tu cuenta, sin embargo aquí es Distinto, aquí si se te da un Tutorial (Gracias Dios mío, ya era hora) te enseñan absolutamente todo, e incluso hay estrategias especiales para todos y cada uno de los personajes, todos los veteranos del juego anterior están presentes, e incluso algunos tienen movimientos nuevos, también hay varios personajes nuevos, los cuales le dan fresquedad al mismo y añaden más variedad al elenco. Otra cosa a recalcar es que en comparación a su anterior entrega este juego tiene una Inteligencia artificial mucho más dura de pelar, en Calamity Trigger podias adaptarte relativamente rápido a la IA del juego y derrotarla fácilmente, aquí no es tan sencillo, toda la IA del juego fue rediseñada y esta vez es más difícil de vencer, básicamente la IA de aquí si es competente en comparación a su antecesora.

[h1]CONTROLES[/h1]
El juego se puede jugar de 2 formas, con teclado, o con Mando, se recomienda más que todo la segunda. Jugar con teclado no es exactamente difícil si eres una sola persona, sin embargo las asignaciones de los botones de función son algo cuestionables, en el caso del jugador uno los botones de movimiento son las flechas, y los botones de acción son el teclado numérico, el cual no todos los teclados tienen, solo los teclados de rango extendido tienen dicho panel, esto limita personas con teclados que no son de rango extendido a usar el segundo mando, lo cual no es exactamente placentero, no por el sentido de ser el número 2, sino por las asignaciones, las del segundo mando son las típicas WASD para movimiento y UIOJKL para los botones de acción, pero los botones de Start y Secect son Shift y Tab… esto puede ser confuso y en Steam eso es un problema, ya que puedes estar en el modo versus, quieras ver tus logros o algo por el estilo y accidentalmente actives al segundo jugador, esto en teclados que no son de rango extendido puede ser un gran problema, y más cuando no puedes cambiar las asignaciones de los botones en los menús, pero bien por ti si logras acostumbrarte. Por otro lado, está la opción de jugar con Mando, el Juego acepta Xinput, o sea mandos de Xbox, pero no acepta nada más, para usar otros controles, como genéricos o de PS3, tendrías que usar software de terceros para que tu control sea reconocido como mando de Xbox, sin embargo, en comparación a jugar con teclado es una opción mucho mejor. BlazBlue es un 2D Figther de 4 botones, y el Control de Xbox cumple con esa necesidad perfectamente, lo cual hace que el Mando de Xbox sea una de las mejores opciones para jugar.

[h1]MODOS DE JUEGO[/h1] - Aparte de tener los mismos modos de juego que su antecesor, incorpora varios mas:
[b]TUTORIAL:[/b] Este es el modo que le hacía falta a Calamity Trigger, y que es muy bien recibido aquí, ya que ahora si puedes aprender lo básico del juego, aparte, como tutorial es de hecho una buena introducción a los juegos de pelea en 2D, te enseñan movimiento, bloqueos, barreras etc…
[b]UNLIMITED MARS:[/b] Es básicamente lo mismo que Score attack, la diferencia es que este ya es en ámbito competitivo, la IA es más fuerte y puedes publicar tu puntaje en línea.
[b]CHALLENGE:[/b] El modo desafío contiene pruebas independientes para cada personaje, aquí es donde aprendes a hacer combos con cada uno básicamente, una gran herramienta para pulir tus habilidades con los personajes, y complementarlas después en el modo de Practica.
[b]ABYSS:[/b] El modo Abismo consiste en que tienes que ir descendiendo hacia el abismo de Kagutsuchi, empiezas en el Nivel 1, y vas descendiendo cada vez más y más (Hasta un teórico máximo Nivel 1000), a medida que vas ganando combates, puedes ir desbloqueando y comprando mejoras para tu personaje, ya que cada vez tus oponentes irán siendo más fuertes, algunos tendrán mejoras en ataque, defensa, movilidad, entre otros, asi que deberás de aprovechar esas mejoras. Entre otras cosas si pierdes puntos de vida durante la partida recuperaras parte de esos puntos al ganar cada pelea, pero no todos, asi que debes de cuidar tu barra de vida, es la única que tendrás.
[b]REPLAY THEATER:[/b] El Modo teatro es donde puedes revivir partidas guardadas, ya sea para verlas simplemente o analizarlas a fondo y ver que falencias o aspectos a mejorar hay en tu combate. funciona tanto para partidas locales como en Linea.
[b]NETWORK:[/b] Es el modo online del juego, puedes armar partidas por medio de Matchmaking, jugar casuales o competitivas con amigos o cualquier jugador del mundo.

[h1]DESTACABLES[/h1]
BlazBlue: Conitinuum Shift Extend, es la mejor opción para introducirse a BlazBlue, ¿se acuerdan que arriba dije que Este juego en su modo historia tenía un resumen de Clamity Trigger? Bueno, esto hace que jugar el juego anterior básicamente sea una perdida, ya que aquí por lo menos te enseñan como jugar, el juego no se siente incompleto y básicamente tiene todo el contenido del anterior (No es su totalidad exactamente) la única razón por la cual jugar Calamity Trigger teniendo esto en cuenta seria, que te guste completar cosas al 100%, ya que pues a pesar de todo, lo que tiene CT que CS no tiene seria gran parte de la galería, que es más que todo imágenes y Wallpapers.
En comparación a su antecesor los movimientos de los personajes fueron ligeramente rediseñados para que conectar combos sea más efectivo, aparte que el juego se siente más rápido y balanceado que su antenesor… Supongamos que Calamity Trigger tenía una velocidad de 80 KM/h, Bueno, Continuum Shift va a 100 KM/h, en si el juego se siente más sólido, más rápido, y más fácil de aprender.

[h1]VEREDICTO[/h1]
¿Quieres pelea? éntrale al BlazAzul – [b]7.5/10[/b] - Bueno, necesita dedicación si quieres volverte bueno y completarlo de paso. Si no haz jugado al anterior no te pierdes de nada básicamente.

เนื้อเรื่องในภาคนี้หลายคนยกให้เป็น Masterpiece ของ Series นี้เลยทีเดียว
เกมเพลย์โดยรวมแล้ว FPS ดรอปค่อนข้างเยอะมาก ซื้อมาตอนแรก 60 เล่นไปสัก 4-5 ชม 57 ลบลงใหม่อีกทีเหลือ 49 HOLY S.H.I.T
และโหมด Story ในเกมนี้จะสอนคุณว่าไม่จำเป็นต้องชนะเสมอไปเพื่อฉากจบที่สวยงาม 555555
ทางด้าน OST นี้โคตรจะคลาสสิกชอบมากโดยส่วนตัว เสียงพากย์มีทั้ง ENG และ JAPAN ซึ่งค่อนข้างดีเลยทีเดียว
โหมดในการเล่นภาคนี้มีให้ค่อนข้างเยอะรองลงมากจากภาค Chronophantasma

อวยมาเยอะละ ข้อเสียกันบ้าง
-FPS ตอนเล่นครั้งแรก 60 สักพัก 57 ลบลงใหม่ทีเหลิือ 49 เงี่ยจะร้องไห้ กด Combo ไปได้ไงละ 
-การกดท่าหรือ INPUT ในภาคนี้จะกดค่อนข้างยากกว่าสองภาคต่อไปอย่างมาก !!! ใครไม่ชินจังวะอาจจะหัวร้อนได้
+/-Hidden Boss ใน ARCADE นี้ทำมากะจะไม่ให้ผ่านกันเลยทีเดียวเพราะมันเ-ี้ยจิงๆ
+/-ออนไลน์ในเกมนี้แถบหาคนเล่นด้วยไม่ได้แล้ว แต่ถ้าซื้อมาเล่นกับเพื่อนก็ไม่มีปัญหานี้อีกเช่นเดียวกัน
โดยส่วนรวมแล้วให้ 7/10 ให้เยอะเพราะ FPS มันรันที่ 60 เนี่ยละกดคอมโบไม่ไปหัวร้อนอีก

34794255.review:
TLDR: Awesome 2D fighter, online and local multiplayer, great story+great and simple recap of Calamity Trigger's story, Rachel Alucard voices the tutorial.

The second installment of Blazblue taking place right after Calamity Trigger is rich in story like all the BB games as well as in gameplay and mechanics. With the addition of several cool characters, this game amps it right up from the original with improved mechanics, online multiplayer, and it also having a critical piece of the story which is connected between the 4 games. Definitely worth grabbing if you want to learn more about the story and/or add a great fighting game to the collection.

Also it comes with a free soundtrack which is most excellent in my opinion because I can't get enough of these songs!

33346010.review:
I was given the entire bundle, so eventually I'll write out a review for each one.

Now, Continuum Shift, what a Rollercoaster, A lot of good story to cover with in a plethora of characters in which you will have a love and hate relationship (I'm looking at you Relius!) 
To pull off combos is relatively easy if you have experience with Street Fighter, or Tekken. It even has a lazy (Stylish) mode, if you're not good enough to pull off combos. 
Every character has something relatable about them, and how they make the stories is absolutely amazing, even animation scenes.
I'm not too sure what else to say about the series in general as I am not finished with it yet, but eventually you'll see me on each game on the review parts.

Gripes?
Well, only one. The grind through each character's story to find the real ending for them so you can get the true ending. (Don't get me wrong, the Gag reel endings are amazing, and the secondary endings.... not so much...)

32901788.review:
When you first see Blazblue you think of Marvel vs Capcom that's inevitable (So you got yourself a high standard of comparison). Its gameplay, art style and fast paced combat are similar, yet it sets itself appart improving them and also adding some great features that make this a unique series of games. 

Pros
- Entertaining fast paced combat
- The game mixes RPG and Visual Novels elements with deep storytelling setting itself apart.
- It has a wide cast of characters and tells the gamestory from each of their perspectives.
- Local and online multiplayer
- The soundtrack its amazing!

Cons
- The game didn't change that much from BB: Calamity Trigger so you can think of this as a v1.5
- As I told in the pros the story is divided into each characters perspective. So you have some grinding if you just wanna get to the true ending.

Bottomline it's a great game expanding the story and cast of characters from the first one in the series.

Overall Rating 80/100

32042059.review:
[h1]简评[/h1]
[quote]预购了铁拳7，才想起以前买的很多格斗游戏都还没有好好玩过，我是属于那种格斗打得稀烂都是又喜欢玩格斗的类型，虽然玩得不行，但是喜欢格斗华丽的必杀和博弈的感觉，格斗游戏也是没有少买。苍翼默示录听闻了很久，名副其实的买GAL附赠格斗，剧情还挺烧脑的，甚至有不少地方让我有EVA的即视感。不玩故事模式的话，Arcades模式也能基本了解故事的大概，而且Arcades的战斗前的演出效果其实比故事模式的那种gal式的效果好。故事模式到了最后一部分有大量的动画演出，看起来还挺热血的。
[/quote]

[h1]亮点[/h1]
[list]
[*]即使没有玩过前作，也有一个小教室的栏目可以用来复习前作的一些知识和设定，可以说很贴心了
[*]虽然是格斗游戏，但是故事模式有分支选择，选择的不同结局也不同，除了bad-end外还有搞笑结局，而进入bad-end会有个小剧场给你完美结局的选择分支的提示。其实我比较遗憾格斗的胜负影响剧情的地方比较少，绝大部分输了就是game over，如果格斗的胜负弄成分歧点的地方再多一点我觉得会更有意思
[*]有对格斗新人非常友好的“帅气操作系统”，基本就是像动作游戏一样的只需要按轻攻击和重攻击的组合就能打出连技的操作方法，放必杀也只需要按住一个键，用来体验剧情非常爽，当然如果都格斗有自信也可以用传统格斗操作方式来打
[*]剧情采用群像剧的方式演绎，我个人是比较喜欢这种方式的，可以从不同角色的角度体验剧情，可以对剧情有更深的理解
[*]配合剧情会有各种状况出现，比如靠近敌人几秒钟就不能使用招式或者自己某些招式被封印，所以剧情战斗代入感还挺强的，也有不小的难度
[/list]

[h1]优点[/h1]
[list]
[*]全程语音
[*]立绘都很漂亮
[/list]

[h1]缺点[/h1]
[list]
[*]过场CG大部分还行，但也有少数几张明显画崩了
[*]退出游戏时会卡住10多秒，不知道是不是我个人的问题
[*]表现是实在是很有限，尽管声优很卖力，但大部分场景还是只能靠脑补
[*]播放动画的时候中文字幕会有延迟，不知道是不是只有中文会这样
[/list]

do you know what most of the fighting games do lack ? a fully detailled tutorial mode , this game has actually more than a tutorial mode to make you experience the perfection of fighting games .
for a price of 20€ you get a +20 hours story mode , an arcade mode , an endless mode , score attack ...etc...
you even do get the bonus content for free which has soundtracks and an art collection .

i've spent nearly 60 hours and yet i've only done 46% of the game and it's totally worth the full price if you want a long-ass game .

the gameplay is balanced , you get a total of 19 ( a total of 38 if we count their alternative form ) , the gameplay has some nice graphics , a nice collection of background soundtracks  , animated cinematics ...etc... what else do you need for a good game ?

i don't advise you to buy this for the online part of the game , because it's completly dead and is p2p based sadly which is a bad downside , but  don't forget that you are able to play other modes so yeah , that's fine .

i wish i had more words to describe how worth it the game is . i'll give it a 10/10

31673597.review:
Si el primer BlazBlue era bueno, este directamente lo mejora pero bestialmente.

Personalmente, este es el juego que estableció el combate del resto de la saga, como pasó con la saga Assasin's Creed, donde el II estableció las verdaderas bases de los futuros juegos, ya que desde mi punto de vista, el salto de mejora que hay entre el Calamity Trigger y este, es igual que el de este y el Chrono Phantasma. Sin embargo, opino que este tiene más mérito, por no mencionar que este juego introdujo el modo Abyss, el cual se ha mantenido en los siguientes.

El modo Historia es prácticamente igual que en su predecesor, pero a mejor. Sin embargo, opino que el mejor modo de Historia es el del Chrono Phantasma. Pero en este juego es donde la historia parece que por fin avanza bastante y no se queda tan ''encerrada''.

No es el mejor BlazBlue, pero en rebajas tiene un precio muuuy bueno, y personalmente es al que más cariño le tengo. Además, para mí posee la mejor banda sonora de la saga, y encima te regalan las canciones de los nuevos personajes, así como un libro de arte. No puedo quejarme ^.^

30365208.review:
[h1]The wheel of fate is turning![/h1]

BlazBlue Continuum Shift Extend is an updated version to the second installment of the BlazBlue franchise, which is a combination of 2D fighting game and visual novel. Its Character Roster consists of 19 unique fighters. Each of them features a completely different playstyle and follows its own storyline, filled with lots of voiced dialogue and cutscenes. 

The game offers you 10 different game-modes to choose from, which'll definitely keep you busy for a long time. I especially recommend looking into the Tutorial-Mode, as it explains everything from the basics of 2D fighting game mechanics to the unique systems of BlazBlue.

Storywise there's no fighting game that could even slightly compare. BlazBlue has built a huge universe around the so called [i]"13. Hiarchial City Kagatsuchi"[/i], that it'll get you pretty confused at some points. Fortunately there's a series of small episodes called [i]"Teach Me, Miss Litchi!"[/i], that'll help the player to understand the story and certain aspects of the game.


[u][b]Pro's[/b][/u]
+ online multi-player
+ local multi-player
+ 19 playable characters
+ [u]10 different game modes[/u]
+ 29 unique stages
+ enjoyable storyline
+ voiced dialogue
+ soundtrack included
+ beginner-friendly
+ [u]teach me, Boobielady![/u]

[u][b]Con's[/b][/u]
- game runs on 720p
- UI


BlazBlue Continuum Shift is undoubtedly a game I would recommend to anyone who hasn't played it yet. Its many aspects should surely appeal to a great variety of gamers, from fighting game enthusiasts to visual novel fans, eager to enjoy a well written storyline.

No llevo mucho jugado al juego pero creo que puedo dar una opinión más o menos decentilla.

En su momento me hice al 100% la versión DVD de Calamity Trigger, y Continuum Shift ha sido una grata sorpresa gracias a las mejoras que incluye en el plano jugable (entre ellas el equilibrio de Rachel y especialmnte Jin, elegido de los marrulleros en el online de CT) La adaptación de la historia de CT para introducirnos a CS es genial especialmente si has jugado al primero, porque empiezas a notas las pequeñas diferencias que llevarán al cambio contínuo. Es muy agradable el hecho de que en su segunda entrega siga conservando la chispa en ese sentido.

Ahora, las quejas. No lo encuentro tan redondo como Calamity Trigger. Para empezar los gráficos han pegado un bajonazo en nitidez, es notable sobre todo mirando a las ilustraciones y portraits de los personajes en el modo historia, pero in-game también se nota. En segundo lugar, a menos que avance en la historia y cambie la cosa, a Lambda no le pega [i]Awakening the Chaos[/i] como tema principal siendo básicamente una marioneta de Kokonoe (era un tema brutal para Nu13 sin embargo) Y en tercero la ausencia de compatibilidad directa con mandos Dinput - A menos que me esté perdiendo algo - es un serio revés.

Me falta probar el resto de modos y meterme en el online, pero por el momento lo recomiendo bastante. Sólo no esperéis una calidad de imagen que rivalice con la de Calamity Trigger.

26676134.review:
Blazblue: Continuum Shift Extend is a 2D fighter that brings you fast pace gameplay fit for beginners and veterans of fighting games and an amazing original soundtrack composed by Guilty Gear's Daisuke Ishiwatari.
The game offers you a variety of game modes.

Tutorial allows you to get the feel of the game if you're a new player or new to fighters.

Versus is your local player vs player or Player vs CPU.

Network is the online versus mode however its most likely dead at this point with the newer installments out unless you ask friends or on the Steam community boards for people to play with.

The Story mode is presented in a visual novel fashion with the occasional battle, this mode offers the player the option to view both the rework of the first installment Clamity Trigger or Continuum Shift's story, allowing the player to move at their own pace through the story to achieve three endings for a character; True and Bad which both tie in with the story's plot device, as well as a gag ending, which a few continue into the next installment. Note that some endings have a requirement such as losing to a certain opponent or Jin and Makoto who can only choose their gag reel option by viewing their true ending.

The Arcade mode has you fight ten computer opponents, the tenth being a boss version of either Hazama or Ragna depending on your chosen fighter as well as the secret boss Mu-12. The arcade bosses can be difficult due to their unique attribute and damage.

The madness that is Unlimited Mars mode is where you fight the whole cast in their boss forms, this mode was made with the intention to make you frustrated or to challenge hardcore players, you do get an achievement for losing five times other than that i see no reason to chose this mode over the others. 

Abyss mode has you fight a wave of CPU opponents as you make your way to the bottom of the dungeon, leveling up amd customizing your fighter along the way as well as earning currency to use in the gallery.

The Gallery is where you can spend the ingame currency to buy art, character colors, boss characters who can only be used in versus and training mode as well as listen to music tracks and voice lines. Note that some content is locked out until you reach a certain level e.g. Lewd art and boss characters. 

In all honesty I'd only really recommend getting this if you're someone who is new to the series and is interested in getting into Blazblue's story and characters as most of the competitive scene and online players have moved onto the newest installment (Chrono Phantasm Extent on Steam and Central Fiction for consoles/Arcades) and players like me who already purchased it on console and/or handheld won't be getting much out of it besides playing it with others on Steam and getting the soundtrack.

TL;DR Buy it if you're new to the series or buy it if you wish to experience those gag reels again, view the gallery or get the soundtrack that is included with the game.

[EARLY REVIEW - 3 HOURS PLAYED]

Already played it for 3 hours, and I'm gonna say that this game is very good.

I am not into online multiplayer, so I'm glad that this game offers many single-player modes (story, arcade, abyss, unlimited mars).
The mechanic feels a bit different from mainstream fighting games. Every character has their oen treat. You can't just use the same combo for every character. You need training for mastering each character (and so far I could only play "properly" as Noel Vermillion). It will take your time, but that's worth it.
The story so far is fairly good. It is presented in visual novel-ish style between each battle. You can change the voice acting in either English or Japanese, so take your choice.

So much modes, interesting character background amd story, heavy-combo combat system. This game is managed to keep me busy and entertained.

8.5/10

24923651.review:
Before playing this, you should consider playing Blazblue: Calamity Trigger. While this has a remastered story of CT included, it's best to start from the beginning anyway, and the remaster doesn't come without its issues, including writing, changes in certain voice cast, and glaring typos.

Story: Amazing, but a little complex. There are things that no matter how easy you catch on will make very little logical sense. Other than that, the writing is very top notch; hillarious when it needs to be and emotional when it needs to be.

Characters: Like with Guilty Gear, from the same creators, this has a very diverse set of characters, from a gun-toting, shy Norvis Orbis Librarium officer to a seemingly robotic samurai. You'll be able to really root for the main character, and love to hate the main villain. 

Gameplay: Not only are the characters diverse in personality and aesthetics, they're also very distinguished by their move sets. Namely their Drive move. From being able to charge up a heightned version of your own attacks, to compensating for a shorter range by letting you fly across the stage, to even being able to effectively parry and turn the battlefield in your favor, everyone has something different and great to bring to the table for different play styles. With it's diverse and very quick playing style, it is also pretty difficult to learn and, if you're not too used to arcade style fighting games already, very difficult to master with its complex combos requiring very effective timing.

Sound: The music is unforgettable and epic, and the voice acting on either side (Japanese and English) is great. A lot of people have noted the changes with Bang Shishigami (from Tony Oliver to Steve Kramer) and Hazama/Yuuki Terumi (Erik Davies to Doug Erholtz) with some disdain. In my honest opinion, while Bang's voice actor change isn't for the better, Kramer does a good job at times where not much energy is needed. Otherwise, he does sound very strained and forced. The change on Hazama/Yuuki Terumi on the other hand is a different story to me. Davies originally sounds very goofy for Hazama and is hard to take seriously. Erholtz plays the role much more slyly, but still gives off being mostly human. Where Davies did shine before was with Terumi, letting the goofiness of Hazama take form of over-the-top hammy with the alter-ego. Erholtz isn't bad at all as Terumi, but he does admittedly sound like he's trying to hard to sound like Mark Hamil's Joker.

Art: This is some of the best looking designs and artwork for an anime style video game. The use of 2D sprites is certainly to the game's advantage.

Overall: There's a good reason why this was my favorite fighting game before Chrono Phantasma. It was a lot of fun single player and with friends, and it kept my attention with an engrossing, but complex storyline. It has flaws here and there, but it's very much worth a try if you're a fan of fighting games. If you aren't, then I highly recommend either viewing the story online or watching the Blazblue Alter Memory anime that focuses on the main storyline.

24919664.review:
BlazBlue: Continuum Shift - это прямой сиквел игры BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger, представляющий из себя смесь файтинга и визуальной новеллы. На ПК игра пришла сразу в виде третьего издания (о чём говорит приписка Extend), со всеми улучшениями и дополнениями. Но обо всём по-порядку.

[h1]Немного истории[/h1]
Как водится у файтингов от Arc System Works, игра сначала вышла на игровых автоматах, а спустя полгода её улучшенную версию выпустили и на консолях. Но после этого игра успела получить ещё две ревизии: Continuum Shift II, которую консольщики получили как бесплатное обновление к оригинальной Continuum Shift, и самостоятельная версия Continuum Shift Extend. Её то нам нам и выпустили на ПК.

[h1]Игра как файтинг[/h1]
Если рассматривать данную игру чисто как файтинг, то даже на момент выхода игры в Стиме она уже по сути была устаревшей. Консольщики в то время давно уже играли в третью часть игры (BlazBlue: Chronophantasma). Из-за чего некоторые любители файтингов сильно возмущались. Но, как я уже говорил ранее, BlazBlue - это далеко не только файтинг.

[h1]Игра как визуальная новелла[/h1]
И вот тут мы подходим к той части игры, которая никогда не устареет. Continuum Shift - это вторая часть длиннющей визуальной новеллы с огромным количеством загадок и неожиданными поворотами сюжета. Доля тех, кто по какой-либо причине не захотел или не смог прочитать Calamity Trigger, разработчики добавили в Extend версию пересказ событий первой части. Так что, в принципе, можно начинать играть и с этой части.

[h1]Сюжет[/h1]
В лучших традициях первой части, Continuum Shift продолжает удивлять неожиданными поворотами и открытиями. Как и раньше вы находитесь в гуще событий, не особо понимая мотивацию персонажей, и обо всём приходится догадываться самостоятельно. Но даже полное прохождение игры оставит вас с огромным количеством вопросов, на многие из которых вы найдёте ответы только в [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/388750/]третьей части[/url].

[h1]Порядок прохождения[/h1]
Если вы не читали [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/263300]Calamity Trigger[/url], я бы посоветовал начать с неё. Пересказ, имеющийся в Continuum Shift Extend, хоть и даёт вам понять, что произошло в первой части, но он не даёт подробностей. Большинство персонажей в пересказе практически не раскрыты, а шутки, пришедшие и Calamity Trigger, вам могут быть просто непонятны.

В отличие от первой части, аркадный режим в Continuum Shift, мягко говоря, не особо богат на оригинальный контент. В основном он лишь показывает один из ключевых моментов истории, который вы и так увидите, проходя режим историй. Так что можно обойтись и без аркады,

[h1]Аниме[/h1]
По первым двум частям игры был снят аниме-сериал BlazBlue: Alter Memory. Уместить в 12 серий даже одну игру непросто, но авторы попытались уместить сразу две. Сюжет Calamity Trigger вообще попытались рассказать в первых двух сериях. Как нетрудно догадаться, ничем хорошим всё это дело не закончилось. Зрители, не знакомые с оригинальными играми, мягко говоря, не оценили. Да и у фанатов игр покромсанный сюжет восторга как-то не вызвал.

Но как закрепляющий материал после прохождения Continuum Shift посмотреть аниме вполне можно. Некоторые вещи в сериале преподносятся более открыто. Так что, если понравилась игра, советую посмотреть и сериал.

[h1]Брать или нет?[/h1]

REVIEW:
Blazblue CSE is a 2 player 2d anime fighting game from ArcSys that features local vs, online vs, and plenty of singleplayer content. Matches are tense and fast paced. CSE is not the latest version of BB, so I would recommend it only if you can't commit to the newer more expensive versions yet or want to play the story mode in order before the later games.

I'd like to make special note that BB:CSE contains a remastered version of the first game's story (Calamity Trigger) which is very much appreciated.

23980390.review:
I had a hard time deciding whether to recommend this or not. Ultimately, I think it's probably the best entry point into the series, for a number of reasons. It's just that... it's not Guilty Gear.

Pros:
* Gameplay is good. As far as fighting games go, Blazblue is way up there. Lots of complex mechanics, but nothing that will keep you from playing and learning on one of the easier settings.
* Soundtrack is nice. Again, it isn't Guilty Gear, but I still think it's pretty good.
* Voice acting is also great. If you can ignore some of the squeaky-voiced characters, like Platinum.
* Loads of content. You can sink dozens of hours into this game.

Cons:
* Character design. It's horrible. Many characters just look like cardboard anime tropes. The female chracters are distractingly boob-centric, which is kind of cliche for an anime-esque game. Also, quite a few of the design are ripped straight out of Guilty Gear.
* Plot. I don't know how they did it just two games into the series, but it's so convoluted I think a Marvel comics writer would have a hard time figuring out what was going on. That said, this one also has an easier to swallow version of the first Blazblue's story. So now, instead of being completely incomprehensible, it's just ridiculous. That still makes this game more accessible than the first Blazblue, though. The worst part about the plot? It moves inches at a time. If you're expecting anything major to happen plot-wise in this game, you're going to be sorely disappointed. So even if you do manage to wrap your head around this thing, there's no payoff to be had.

Buy this if you liked Guilty Gear, but don't expect to be Guilty Gear, I guess.

绝对的推荐！一流的音乐，大牌的声优不说，属于游戏核心的故事及游戏性也都是超级棒的，我想，如果IGN来对这款游戏评分的话，应该最少也有9.5分吧，无论你是不是苍翼默示录的粉丝，我都推荐这款游戏。当然，网上有很多说动作慢，玩起来卡的问题，其实只要在游戏里把与画面有关的都调到最低就行了，而在语言方面这款游戏实际上是自带繁体中文的[spoiler]虽然在游戏右键属性上显示的是简体中文[/spoiler]。而剧情方面呢，本人用了36小时左右把开始的那个前一部大致剧情，开场动画，18个角色，最后的两个追加故事，以及真实结局全部达成了complete，又用了1个多小时把5个莉琪老师教教我全部以答对状态通过，[spoiler]没有了前作那种什么地方都必须输一次才能增加角色剧情完成度的坑爹设定，但其实只是相当于减轻了这种程度，这些角色基本上都是必须在某次战斗失败后才能解锁隐藏要素，所以你又不得不一次一次试[/spoiler]建议追求complete通关剧情的朋友在打剧情时把分歧点，记录位置以及战斗输赢情况记在一个小本上或一张纸上，那样能最大限度节省时间，理清头绪，尤其是在进入非真实结局后特别有帮助，[spoiler]最好还是用横过来的树形图形式记[/spoiler]最后，此款游戏在价格方面有点小贵，如果可以还是建议等打折后再入手比较合算。

中学时代的回忆，想着当初顶着高考压力每天拿着一个PSP练习连段到深夜的就为了第二天和朋友们联机掏出PSP展现出一个令人惊叹的连段。想想那时候的自己真的是什么都不会，不懂立回不懂骗投不懂压制不懂起攻，只知道不停的摸奖摸奖摸奖，然后摸到了就展现出自己训练房泡出来的那一套。虽然很弱，但是和朋友一起打游戏的乐趣是真切的。

22744698.review:
BlazBlue: Continuum Shift Extend, which I’ll refer to as CSE from now on, is a 2D fighting game by Arc System Works which has been on the consoles for a while, but was recently ported onto Steam for Windows following their success with their port of the first game in the series, BlazBlue: Calamity Trigger.
Gameplay

A lot of people find it rather difficult to play fighting games using the Mouse and Keyboard setup, so the game does support controllers, along with local versus mode so you can play against your friends. When compared to other fighters such as Street Fighter, Blazblue’s mechanics are more complex and deeper so its not as great of a pick-up for players looking to learn how to play fighting games but like all things, if you’re dedicated enough to practice, you’ll be able to play the game no problem, though it may take some time compared to people with experience in other fighters. However, if you’re just looking for casual play with friends,  the game comes with a beginner mode, called Stylish, which gives the user one-button combos, similar to Persona 4 Arena’s combat system. ss+(2014-12-12+at+07.48.55)Whether you’re new to the BlazBlue series or fighting games in general, CSE offers a fairly in-depth tutorial on the game’s mechanics and general advice for each character in the game so players wanting to learn the franchise can do so without pressure in the tutorial and training modes.

Other gameplay modes included in the game are:

    Versus – A standard 1v1 match against a friend or a computer.
    Score Attack – 1 player fights various computer controlled characters to get a high-score.
    Unlimited Mars – Score Attack with smarter bots and enemies have stronger and alternate abilities.
    Challenge – 1 player attempts to perform combinations of moves (combos) fluidly on a passive bot.
    Abyss – A pseudo-dungeon where players can buy upgrades to their characters to fight against regular and Unlimited Mars

For collectors, you earn currency to buy items with in the gallery, such as the boss characters from Unlimited Mars and the Story, artwork, and additional voice-packs. In addition to all these extra modes that provide plenty to do, especially if you’re still a beginner and have a hard time completing certain modes, the game also comes with a story mode, which I thought was rather long and text-heavy for a fighting game. Some people may like it, others probably won’t since fighting games aren’t usually known for their story. The story is fully voiced in English, also Japanese as DLC which is currently being included for free, presented in a similar style to visual novels, with the character model appearing on screen standstill, and occasional artwork.

2014-12-12_00004

The game’s main story is coherent enough and even gives you a playthrough of the previous games’ main plotline, but the writing itself made various out of place references to internet culture and was, in general, so bad that you hope they were trying to be ironic. They have to be right? No one could possibly think naming your main character The Bloodedge was a good idea. Right?

2014-12-12_00005

Apart from the main storyline, is a series of lore, entitled, Teach Me Miss Litchi!, which doesn’t offer anything in terms of gameplay, but creates some humorous skits and touch upon the world’s lore, which I admittedly do not follow very well since anything that has to do with multiple universes and time travel just flies right over my head.

The game’s online is rather barebones, but functions without any major hiccups. The standard amount of settings for 1v1 versus like, the number of rounds, duration of each round, how many players can be in the lobby, who gets to participate in the next round, usage of special characters, and whether to make a private/public/ranked (to play for Player Skill Rating and earn a spot on the leaderboards) lobby are all included, but not much more.
Graphics

Being a 2D fighter, the game’s graphics were never that demanding to begin with so being on the PC doesn’t offer as much in terms of graphical improvements as it would with other genres. While it does output in “native” 1080p compared to the consoles’ 720p output, it doesn’t seem to do anything as the graphics both in-game and in the menus look identical to their console counterparts, even with Anti-Aliasing set to 4x (the maximum the game allows).
Click on the image for a full-size view.

Click on the image for a full-size view.

The artwork and in-game backgrounds are very visually appealing, but doesn’t really mean much when the in-game character models and even the menus are so jagged.
Audio

The game’s voice acting was done fairly well in both the English and Japanese dubs of the game. I thought the game’s soundtrack was really solid, but lacked variety as  pretty much every track in the game was a variation of fast-paced, anime theme song, so people who don’t enjoy that style of music probably won’t enjoy this game’s soundtrack either. The game’s sound effects were varied enough too so you have a good idea of what’s happening and won’t get confused by the verbal diarrhea that tends to occur when people start executing faster combos since all the game’s characters seem to love shouting out what move they’re using.
Verdict

One of the issues of the game I didn’t talk about previous was that this was a port of a game originally released 4 years ago on consoles, with the DLC included in the Extend edition only being a year younger. In that time, consoles have already received the series’ next installment, Chronophantasma, which is likely to be ported onto Steam eventually as well. The game also carries a $30 price point on Steam while you could it for $20 on consoles rather easily.
Pros

    A lot of game modes
    Great soundtrack for fans of anime-style songs
    Good art direction
    A fairly detailed story mode for a fighting game
    Very deep game mechanics

Cons

    Not as many characters compared to other fighting franchises
    Cringe inducing writing
    No real graphics upgrades from the console version so everything looks jagged and blurry
    No variety in the soundtrack
    Barebones online
    Outdated game
    Price point

BlazBlue: Continuum Shift Extend is an extremely solid fighter in terms of gameplay mechanics and the variety of modes you can play offline, however the game’s online features are rather minimal and despite the upgrade from console to PC hardware, no real improvements are made to the game’s visuals. The game is also a hard sell since the game’s price point is extremely high for a port of a 4 year old game, especially when you know the sequel is already out on consoles and probably will be ported to the PC as well. If you’re looking a relatively challenging, fast-paced fighting game and don’t mind the game’s cost despite being outdated, CSE is definitely a game you should pick up, and a solid:
8/10

21673247.review:
BlazBlue Continuum Shift Extend es una entrega que supera bastante a su anterior Calamity Trigger  por el hecho de que agrega nuevos personajes, tiene mejores escenarios y diseños ademas de mayor historia.
Empezando con el modo historia que es uno de los mayores fuertes de la saga, ya que para ser un juego de peleas esta muy bien ambientado, con una historia bastante profunda y bien explicada con cada uno de los puntos de vista de los personajes.
Los diseños en combate y en la historia de los personajes ya existentes son los mismos que en calamity trigger los cual puede ser bueno o malo dependiendo del gusto de cada uno.
El sistema multijugador online, a pesar de estar algo muerto actualmente, es bueno y no hay tanto lag como se podria esperar, ciertamente los personajes pueden estar bastante rotos pero con suficiente entrenar se puede superar todo.
Definitivamente recomiendo el juego.

21164096.review:
不好玩。

说实话我很不喜欢，曾经GGXX也玩过也是很不喜欢。这次看它说自己是2D格斗什么最高峰，我决定再试试，还是玩不下去。

画面：我不知道那些说画面好的人，不会觉得粗糙的人物和细腻背景很不搭吗？当然，画面不差的。但是我更想说，这个游戏的UI太过花哨，人设也是哗众取宠，个人感觉很不耐看，俨然国产页游的日风高端版，有时简直觉得去掉这些胡里花哨的UI这游戏还不如KOF94那年代的画面统一自然。我更喜欢SKULLGIRLS的人设，简单有特色就好，每个角色过目不忘，没那么多花边蕾丝边白带什么的。既然你吹你是2D最高峰，我就随便提个真侍魂、侍魂3这种老古董跟你比，知道的人想想看哪个更美。[spoiler]BB有时画面太花背景太乱人物非主流导致我连人都看不清判定全靠听力我会乱说吗？[/spoiler][spoiler]你知道街霸4网战使用率99%的地图就是什么都没有的练习场格子图就是为了专注格斗吗？[/spoiler]

系统：操作流畅，但是系统说实话没感觉到什么特色，SNK开创超杀，街霸33有BLOCKING系统，DOA有返技，MK有终结技，这些都是格斗界的创新，而这个顶多是个动作自由度更高的KOF，恕我手残玩不出什么信仰来，如果说我的游戏龄是N年，那么我的FTG龄就是N年，一直以来最爱就是格斗游戏，但是实在感受不到GGXX和BB的乐趣。[spoiler]什么？你说加入了GALGAME元素？呵呵你知道KOF13加入了开场白多磨人多讨厌吗……[/spoiler]

音乐：玩过后可以说我是毫无印象[spoiler]只记得入场前双方头像画面的音乐好难听，好像洗澡洗到一半遇到火警走难你还尿急此时你还有十几层楼要跑的心情，你听听街霸4的入场前火焰爆炸背景的哪个音乐？[/spoiler]，敢比街霸和KOF的音乐吗？敢和暗荣脱裤魔比吗？敢和KONAMI比吗？要真比肯定比不了，我的意思是人家很明显写曲子有个目的，就是配合角色或者场景还要洗脑还要百听不厌，现在BB的情况是我连个调都没记住。

总评：不错的游戏，论制作其实是很用心的，但是论游戏论论特色顶多是个贴牌的MUGEN的水平。2D格斗最高峰这种词还是不要说比较好，因为你背景好像是3D的，人家街霸只不过人物也3D了玩法还是2D的，可能我这差评纯粹是较真“2D格斗最高峰”这个词，信仰党可以无视。

之所以其他优秀的格斗游戏都各有特色甚至返璞归真，或许是因为格斗游戏最后总会归于小众和硬核，而硬核玩家往往希望专心比赛，格斗游戏到了高手过招的时候往往反而简单朴素如猜拳一般，这个游戏所有吸引人的日系元素拿来出动漫是很好，拿来做格斗的话，很可惜最后都成了干扰和败笔，如果说BB的特色就是这样的，这就是GGXX和BB的特色，对不起，说实话都是别人玩剩下的。个人意见。




另外英文是日本妹子念的吧听哭了，我不相信每盘开场和结束就这么几个单词你念不好，你完全日式口音还好但是明显能听出在努力往标准口音那边靠，这样很辛苦，不要这样。

첫번째 작 "블레이블루 캘러미티 트리거"에서 이야기가 이어지는 2번째작 "블레이블루 컨티뉴엄 시프트"이다.
전작에서 달라진 점이라면 네트워크 플레이(온라인 대전)이 추가되었고,(사실 전작도 있긴 했지만 스팀에 발매되면서 GFTWL가 없어지면서 같이 없어졌다는...)그리고 당연한거지만 신캐릭터가 추가되었고,또 당연하지만 그신캐릭터들의 스토리도 추가되었다.

그리고 설세일의 유혹에 보기좋게 넘어가고 신시리즈 "블레이블루 크로노판타즈마 익스텐드"가 스팀상점에 추가되기 이틀전에 이게임을 샀다... 역시 내 호갱근성은 누가 알아봐줘야해....(사실 리뷰에다가 나 호갱이에요 자랑하는 셈이지만..)

게임플레이야뭐...전작이나 이번작이나 똑같이 대전격투니까 인터페이스를 제외하면 크게 달라지지 않았고,

멀티엔딩도 그렇고 전작에서 개승한점이 많다.

어비스모드라고 적을 쓰려트려가며 아이템을 획득하고 더 강한적과 싸워나가는 모드도 추가되었다.

A VERSÃO DEFINITIVA DO BLAZBLUE PARA STEAM ATÉ O PRESENTE MOMENTO!

BlazBlue é uma série de jogos criada pela Arc System Works (também amplamente conhecida pela série Guilty Gear), com gráficos mesclando 2D com 3D (mas permanecendo com a jogabilidade 2D), e, como Guilty Gear, também muito popularizado com os gráficos estilo 'anime' e com personagens extremamente carismáticos (um salve especial para Taokaka, haha).

Mas falando dessa versão em particular: A Continuum Shift Extend possui um storymode que talvez alguns de vocês podem ficar perdidos (já que a Arc System Works, tem o péssimo costume de lançar versão atrás de versão, com poucas mudanças significativas e em forma de jogo novo), mas existe um resumo dos episódios anteriores, só terem calma que logo verão ao jogarem.

A jogabilidade extremamente amigável (as pessoas que jogam Guilty Gear vão se sentir em casa), gráficos lindos (mesmo para os padrões de hoje), a trilha sonora incrível (que só Guilty Gear para superar) e uma Storyline complexa, recheada de informações poderá te manter bastante ocupado por um bom tempo.

E TUDO QUE ESTAVA EM FALTA NO JOGO ANTERIOR (equilíbrio dos personagens, multiplayer online, e afins...) ESTÁ PERFEITAMENTE AJEITADO... Definitivamente não tem como colocar alguma reclamação no jogo atualmente

E caso não conhaçam a série, a promoção está sempre batendo a porta, trazendo este jogo aos 75%.
Vale muito dar uma conferida!

20798009.review:
Alors que le prochain opus de la saga va montrer le bout de son nez au Japon (sur arcade et eventuellement console...) Steam propose ENFIN BBCSE dans nos belles contrés. Il est assez hallucinant de voir une telle politique de diffusion (la version chronophantasma est dispo sur le PS store PS3, donc c'est pas une histoire de localisation en Europe).

Mais bon parlons du jeu... et bien il est excellent, et même si les puristes du jeu de baston ne jurerons que par leur street fighter chéri, pour ma part je suis un afficionados de la série des Blazblue. Pourquoi ? Pas forcément pour le chara design des persos (même si je ne trouve pas ça désagréable) ni pour la musique (dont les nappes d'orgues gothico machin chose me sortent pas les yeux) mais pour son gameplay. Chaque perso dispose d'un gamesysteme unique basé sur un "drive" qui lui donne sa touche caractéristique. Côté négatif, ça sous entend que le perso n'a pas 50 manière de ce jouer. Côté positif, ça veut dire que vous allez vraiment avoir du choix et pas seulement des variations sur le thème des shoto (oui c'est à toi que je pense Street IV et tes 8 ou 10 perso dragon / boules / tatsu). 

Les graphismes en 2D sont très beau, même si l'abus d'effet de couleur frole parfois l'overdose (enfin c'est pas MVC3 non plus) et ce choix de la 2D se ressent sur le gameplay. Le jeu pousse clairement à l'offensive (avec notamment des barres de spécial qui se vident entre les rounds) et fait la part belle aux air combo et aux juggles (les deux allant souvent de pair).

Cet édition de Blazblue propose un casting vraiment sympa avec notamment Relius et Platinium, cette dernière étant HORRIBLEMENT forte malgré son chara design qui donne envie de brutaliser des petits animaux :)

20750499.review:
[h1]Graphismes:[/h1]
La 2.5D (arènes 3D, personnages et gameplay 2D) de BlazBlue est juste exceptionnelle, avec des animations très fluides (quelque chose de rare dans le domaine des 2D fighters). Chaque personnage est visuellement différent (excepté Lambda-11 et Nu-13, qui sont juste le même sprite avec un swap color, mais c'est justifié dans l'histoire).
[b]Note[/b]: 10/10

[h1]Musique:[/h1]
Prenez de la musique classique, électro, et du Heavy Metal. Melangez le tout. Vous obtenez une magnifique OST de la part de Daisuke Ishiwatari.
[b]Note[/b]: 10/10

[h1]Voice acting:[/h1]
Très bon boulot de la part des acteurs qui ont vocalisés l'intégalité des personnages, et ce en japonais comme en anglais.
Je retire un demi point pour l'acteur de la version japonaise de Ragna, car il fait un peu moins badass.
[b]Note[/b]: 9.5/10

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
Un pur plaisir, que se soit au stick arcade, à la Steam Controller, ou au clavier.
Le jeu propose même un mode de contrôle "Stylish", afin de rendre le jeu plus accessible, même si il se transforme un peu en button mashing.
Il y a également une sélection de mode de jeux, y compris un mode "histoire".
[b]Note[/b]: 10/10

[h1]Histoire:[/h1]
À propos de l'histoire, je la trouve juste géniale et émouvante (celui qui ne ressend rien ou presque lors du chapitre de Noel Vermillion n'est pas un être humain).
Ceux qui achètent BlazBlue Continuum Shift avant Calamity Trigger (et qui pensent que "plus récent" = "mieux") pouront profiter d'un résumé de l'histoire de ce dernier (et avec une meilleure intro) afin de ne pas être totalement largué. En revanche, les premiers chapitres de "Teach Me, Miss Litchi" (des séquences humoristiques permettant d'en apprendre plus sur l'univers de BlazBlue) ne sont disponibles que dans Calamity Trigger.
[b]Note[/b]: 10/10

20118919.review:
BB Vet here, It's a bit pricey but at the end of the day you get what you put in.

PROS:
-Beautifully stunning spritework, backgrounds and HUD, especially for a 2D fighting game.
-Each character is unique in their own way, even with an in depth backstory.
-Hours of fully english dubbed(or japanese if you want) story modes.
-4 button layout is easier for new players being introduced to fighters than your average 6.
-Full Fightstick/Controller support.
-Comes with a special artbook and the soundtrack with some of the battle themes in it.
-Tutorial mode can teach you everything from the bread and butter of a fighter to special character exclusive combos.
-If your a fan of rock/metal THIS SH!T WILL GET STUCK IN YOUR HEAD.
-Specials and astrals, though sometimes difficult to pull off, look stunning.

CONS:
-Lots of characters are NOT noob friendly (I'm looking at the Clovers and Arakune).
-Barely anyone plays online anymore.
-Ragna and Jin are easy for new players, therefore we have an online scene with nothing but them.
-IMPOSSIBLE to play on keyboard
-A bit outdated (Chronophantasma coming january 2k16)
-A tad awkward to configure controls.

It's a solid fighter, but at the same time though miniscule, it has its fair share of problems. I can reccomend this to anyone that's a fan of flashy overthetop (Shonen basically) anime fighters. If you or a friend wants to get into Blazblue, then I highly reccomend this over Calamity Trigger, though I will reccomend playing with someone your skill level or some of the easier CPU's before stepping online. Repeated defeats could discourage a player and ruin their overall experience. I'll be looking forward to the PC release of Chronophantasma, and I'll be hoping they port Central Fiction over too. Overall I'd say 8.5/10.

20111053.review:
Astral Finish intrerrupted by platinum's bubble
fuck platinum
EDIT: how about a serious review this time hm?
BlazBlue Continuum Shift EX is the second BlazBlue game, and the second BB game to be ported to PC
Story: Each character has their own backstories and you can find out a lot about them in the Story campaigns
Graphics: Arenas are low-poly but look nice, splendid spriting for characters and attacks (lambda's astral finish HNNNG)
Gameplay: Fun combo based fast paced 1v1 fighting action, has a variety of different modes. 
Unlike Calamity Trigger this has online play
Sound: Voice acting is good but feels awkward sometimes, japanese voice pack might fix. Your mileage may vary I suppose. SPLENDID music.

STRONG POINTS:
-Varied characters, each character plays differently. From Taokaka's lightning fast dashes and strikes to Tager's slow but strong smashes and Hakumen's counter based fighting there's lots to pick from
-The music. I can't stress this enough, it fits perfectly and sounds very good.
-Lots of unlockables and achievements to keep it fresh and to give players things to aim for

WEAK POINTS:
-Netcode can get stuttery. This will mess you up if someone lags online or has a weak connection.
-Some characters feel slightly overpowered, but this can become bearable with enough experience.
(screw you tager)

Pick this up, maybe get it for a friend or two too, you will have lots of fun if you like fighting games.
Hell, it has lots of content in singleplayer too, but nothing beats the feeling of playing with friends.
Verdict: GET

19806238.review:
Comment dire...
Ce jeu est un excellent jeu de baston. 
j'commence a les collectionner, et j'ai l'impression que chacuns se démarquent.
C'est rapide et nerveux si tu veux t'la jouer pro, c'est hyper simpliste si t'es juste la pour la "detente". C'est dire, même le jeu te propose un mode de jeu ultra simplifié si tu le sens pas trop.

On s'retrouve avec un menu principal qui te propose une floppée de modes de jeux, toujours sur le principe de pêter la gueule a l'adversaire, mais de façons differentes.
Y'a le mode Arcade, story, time attack etc, mais également un mode missions (consistants a enchainer des combos), pour les débutants qui s'disent "mdr j'vais m'la jouer combo et ces connards de japonais arrêterons de me rabaisser"
Mais aussi un mode "unlimited mars" qui est un gros doigt dans le cul de la part des dev, et qui te disent "regarde a quel point t'es une sous merde mdr"

Les personnages sont *en rêgle générale* attachants, et ont tous, je dis bien TOUS une jouabilité differente, si bien que pour chaque perso, on a petit, moyen, gros, et une "capacité" pour le personnage choisi (arme de magical girl, transformations, dashs, coups avec timing..) 

Les sprites et animations : RIEN A DIRE.
C'est tres beau, j'm'en lasse pas.
Ils ont plutôt bien réussi a inserer de la 3D dans les stages, même si sur certains les textures sont euh..comment dire...
Après c'est dans le style manga, t'aimes ou t'aimes pas quoi.

Au niveau des musiques, elles sont pas dégueux, juste facilement oubliables.
on va dire qu'a part la musique qui se déclenche lors de l'ultra, j'ai retenu que le theme de Taokaka. #bestwaifu

La jauge de super se remplis hyper lentement, d'un coté ça évite le spam abusif de super.
Mais croyez moi, y'a rien de plus jouissif dans blazblue que de réussi a placer une ultra. (même si je trouve triste que certaines d'entres elles ne soient pas si impressionantes que ça...)

Le voice acting en anglais, j'ai pas eu le temps d'en profiter, cependant le japonais est...euh...je peux pas trop juger ça en fait.
Je peux juste dire que changer la voix de la présentatrice sur un panel d'une DIXAINE de voix, c'est sympa.
Par contre j'peux vous dire qu'entendre sans arrêt "COUNTER" quand on..bah fait une counter, c'est très irritant.

Voila, j'finis sur une petite note négative, mais si t'as pris la peine de lire cette évaluation, alors tu a constaté que je ne peux que conseiller ce jeu.
Il est jouable pour les débutants, et idéal pour les experts.
Un bon vieux jeu arcade bien du pays du soleil levant. 
Ouééé

19707216.review:
Excellent excellent fighter. Very different and fast-paced. This was my first and only BlazBlue game as of now and I am looking forward to playing more games in the series.

There are only a few things that I can recall that I do not like about this game. All of which have to do with voices. Not to be confused with the voiceovers during a match, those are fine. The story mode drags because of the super slow voiceovers. The voice actors themselves sound great. But it feels like there was no forethought of how the lines would fit together and be paced in the game. It feels even slower than a TV soap opera. Also, the tutorial has the same effect except you can skip through it more easily. Yet you don't really want to blow through the tutorial if you're trying to learn it all... so the plus-side of being able to skip isn't very applicable. I can't emphasize enough how annoying the voiceover in the tutorial is, which is done by the character, Rachel Alucard. Her voice is fine, it's just that it is SO slow. As far as I saw there is no option to turn down just her voice or to turn it off completely. When you're reading along her voice usually lags way behind and it can trip you up when you read ahead which has the side effect of forcing you to follow at her snail pace. I'm not one to pick things apart unless they are really annoying. And the slow character voices... are really annoying.

Everything else is freakin' awesome. Great fighter!

19687723.review:
*As its been announced that Chrono Phantasm Extend is coming to PC, I thought I'd make this review*

This review is lengthy and If you don't have time to just sit and look through it, read a shorter condensed review.

Rare, very rare is it for me to find a game that actually will allow you the chance at a tremendous gameplay and story. Myself, I've never liked the 2d fighting games, but Blazblue really helped change that if only because of its incredible story.

One thing to note though: My original intention for me buying the game was for the story, but the fun gameplay and character variety changed that.

Story wise you won't find much that can compare to some of the complexity that Blazblue is. If you played the original Blazblue and didn't look up anything to understand what was happening and trial-and-error it yourself, you are a trooper. The story is so complicated at times that its hard to distinguish the "right" path from the "wrong" path. Some people take this either good or bad.

For this installment however, they changed the story portion around a bit as its not as complicated to figure out. They also added a bonus for people who did (or didn't) play the original Calamity Trigger. However, that story was reduced in depth and for those who played it, will notice a lot of dialouge change. That however wasn't a bad thing since it gave us a better grounded way to understand this game.

One of the major perks I found with this game's story: It's entirely voice-acted. EVERY single character has a unique voice that's different, they all have a personality, and MY WORD does Hazama sound bloody awesome. Sometimes I wish that Ufotable would just take the dialouge, then animate it into glory. For most of the between people dialouge, I just sat back, closed my eyes, and after the end of their talking, casually hit the A button to proceed to the next. It's so much fun to understand this story.

A flaw to this game however (and to MANY people) is that the story is quite frankly, complicated as stated before. Each characters story takes place at different set, key points, and if you don't have a guide on you, your gonna have a hard time pieceing the story together. To newcomers however I say --- DON"T GIVE UP!!! There is a magnificent story behind this game and you'll miss out if you don't work to understand!

Gameplay is the typical 2d fighting with various moves that are unique to each character. However, they all have a unique way of playing style, feel, reach, and all add some sort of variety to prevent that "stale" air of copy and paste fighting characters. That itself helped me like it more. 

For those who know it, theres nothing like pulling off a Astral Heat against an opponent. Oh, the satisfaction.

A great game that shouldn't be missed, wonderful story, characters, completely voiced, hilarity, fun gameplay, and more.

19351351.review:
I know I don't have many hours on the Steam version, but across all platforms and different games in the series I've sunk literally thousands of hours into BlazBlue. Its great story, amazing characters, fast-paced and relatively well balanced gameplay, and deep mechanics made it my all time favorite video game series. As much as I love and recommend the series, I'll give you a few warnings though:

The story is really big and complicated. Even though this game has a bonus story mode that sums up the events thus far, it's still pretty hard to follow. I recommend taking a look at the wiki if you're interested.

It's pretty tough to learn and very hard to master, especially if you're new to fighting games. Particularly so if you're looking to master an exceptionally demanding character like Carl or Arakune. 

This is not the newest version of the game. In fact, there are two more versions of the game past this (BlazBlue: Chronophantasma and BlazBlue Chronophantasma: Extend, neither of which are available on Steam yet).

That being said, I can't recommend this game enough. In my opinion this is the best fighting game series ever made and if you're even remotely interested in the genre I think you should give it a try!

19155195.review:
Read this if you have a Qanba or PS3/PC only fightstick! Otherwise, uh, have fun with your game that luckily works for you?

The game is rad, but this port is terribly sloppy.  There are like, six companies that make decent arcade sticks for the PC, and unless you happened to buy a stick that is XINPUT friendly (which, if you have a PS3/PC compatible joystick it won't be!), good luck mapping your buttons to anything that makes any sense whatsoever.  I literally couldn't get this game to recognize the start button on my Qanba Q1 (a fine joystick that works great with Skullgirls or USF4), and had to use some sort of DLL wrapper workaround to get it to recognize any inputs at all.  After much fussing around, I was able to get something acceptable, except for the fact that one of the attack keys was irrevocably bound to the "record dummy action" key in training mode, and another was bound to "play recorded action".  So you can just imagine for yourself how that went.  This is not a difficult problem for Arc System Works to fix, and yet here we are, several months after release, with nothing. I hope that they will be more considerate in the creation of future PC ports of their fighting games, because their games are actually quite good (as I'm sure this one could be!).

19007651.review: Ah, BlazBlue Continuum Shift II, the first game of the series I played. I've seen videos on it, I've heard people talking about it. So when I got a system that could play it, I bought it. Sadly it was for the Nintendo 3DS meaning I could not play with others online, just local. Not to say BlazBlue was bad on 3DS, just it could of been better, though too be fair it at least had an animated background unlike a certain Street Fighter port. . . For 3DS. Well my 3DS broke a couple months ago so no more BlazBlue for me, as well as other games I loved playing on that system. But then I saw that BlazBlue Continuum Shift Extend was released for PC and so I used the money I made from selling my most prized possession in all of Gaming to get BlazBlue. . . and other games. Well how is it? Basically the same really, there's probably some technical changes but overall everything seen in Continuum Shift II is all here, the only true noticable differences will be the intro cinematic and the addition of a new character, Relius Clover, or Carl's messed up Father who thought it be cool to turn his Mom and Sister into puppets. BlazBlue can have a heavy story line, or be not-serious-at-all comedic. But who plays games these days for Story? Well you'll probably get curious on it eventually because why not? But out of seriousness the Story will be long, doesn't matter which character you choose so may want to have some snacks around. Although there will be Gag stories which sometimes they're funny and other times they're just, eh. And then there's the arcade mode, you played Street Fighter? Same thing. Only different here is you can do Fatalities. Okay so they call it an Astral Finish but still it's the one move that can instantly finish off a character in an epic display. . . except Arakune who turns into a giant floating ball. Speaking, the characters, you'll either love them or hate them. Each character is different than the other, and each character has a very different personality. From Ragna's troubled ego, Jin's super obsession, Taokaka's hyperactivity, and of coarse Hazama's trollish attitude. And then there's the character who you can't tell the gender because BACKSTORY. . . also has a clear Male and Female voice which reason for being is (again) Backstory. Then there's the special content where you can see concept and fan art as well as seeing some shorts about the series. BlazBlue is clearly not going to be for everyone out there, but it's still a fun game none-the-less. You'll get a sense for other large name games while playing a different game. I say at least try it if you ever get that chance.

A great fighting game, I really like it, and I like some of the characters (like Rachel Alucard), but I gotta say, I just kind of like Guilty Gear XX Accent Core Plus a bit better, mostly because I instantly fell in love with the characters there. Not so much with BlazBlue. Sure, I like one or two of them... but I can't say I love them. That said, their gameplay mechanics are all pretty neat. What, you thought I was talking about their abilities before?

BlazBlue Continuum Shift isn't even bad. It's excellent, in fact. I really like playing as Noel, and I find the combo system to be fun enough, I also like the way that abilities work, and the way that you can chain a lot of them together. There's a lot to like about BlazBlue.

Just, it would probably have made a bigger impression if I hadn't played the sublime Guilty Gear beforehand.

That said, it's likely I am going to be coming back to play this game some more. It is, after all, excellent fun, and there are tons of gamemodes, not to mention the story mode.

18920150.review:
When I initially bought the game and posted this review, I thought it was one of the best fighting games I've touched in a long while. While I wouldn't say that was wrong at the time, with more experience under my belt I would say it's not that worth touching.

To put things into perspective, back then my experience with fighting games was Ultra Street Fighter 4, Skullgirls, Guilty Gear X2 #Reload, Street Fighter 3rd Strike, and a few games from my early childhood that are too fuzzy in my mind to recall. Out of those, the only ones I still like are X2 and 3rd Strike.

After playing this game, I see it has room for better combos while the pacing of the game is really bad compared to other airdasher/anime fighting games. I'd still recommend it as an introduction to the series if you care for story at all, but otherwise just play the sequels or check out the Guilty Gear series. Still a fine game and can recommend, but it doesn't hold up nearly as well as I thought.

18540219.review:
Tras largas horas de juego (y un vicio increíble) he decidido dedicar un poco de mi tiempo para hacer un análisis a esta entrega de Blazblue, ya que se lo tiene muy merecido, bien empecemos por los puntos fuertes:

- La plantilla de personajes es bastante decente, se han añadido bastantes luchadores, ahora hay unos 19 en total, teniendo en cuenta que en blazblue calamity trigger solo había unos 12 disponibles.

- Los personajes son muy carismáticos y cada uno tiene su propio estilo de lucha.

- El arcade es lo clásico, 9 stages y el final stage, que puede resultar un poco difícil si no estás bien familiarizado con los juegos de lucha.

- El Story mode del juego es simplemente fascinante, una historia que al principio te puede resultar algo compleja si no conocías blazblue, aunque viene con un “resumen” del primer juego que te ayudará a entender la historia un poco mejor, resumiendo, la trama es magnífica, no tiene nada que envidiar a otros juegos de lucha. Cada personaje tiene su propia historia, con sus diálogos, y sus tres rutas a completar:  Good ending, bad ending (como el propio nombre indica, el final bueno y el final malo) y el gag reel, que es algo así como la ruta “cómica” del juego. Una vez completada la historia de x personaje, se va desbloqueando a los demás, y así sucesivamente.

- La banda sonora es maravillosa, de diez.

- El Abyss Mode resulta bastante divertido, conforme vas avanzando podrás ir subiendo las estadísticas de tu personaje, y luego se te irán desbloqueando en la tienda.

Ahora vamos con los contras, desde mi punto de vista:

- El online se puede decir que está bastante muerto, a veces podrás encontrar algunas salas creadas por otros jugadores y luchar ahí, pero la gran mayoría de veces no encontraras nadie con quién jugar (sobre todo en los Ranked matches), no obstante hay que decir que para jugar con un amigo es genial y muy divertido, además las peleas suelen estar libre de lag, aunque esto también depende de tu conexión a internet.

- Personajes rotísimos como Tager o Haku-men que pueden sacarte de quicio en numerosas ocasiones.

- Las misiones, que bien pueden parecer fáciles al principio, son jodidamente difíciles mientras más avanzas, teniendo que memorizar varios combos y hacerlos en el momento EXACTO, y con rapidez. Tiene un nivel de dificultad bastante intenso, muy difíciles de realizar a menos que seas pro.

Y por último hay que destacar que si vais a jugar, lo más recomendable es utilizar gamepad, ya que con el teclado se te puede hacer muy complicado. No hay nada más que añadir, si te encantan los 2D fighter  y eres fan de la saga guilty gear, blazblue definitivamente es de lo mejorcito que te vas a encontrar por aqui, un 10 merecido, y ahora toca esperar a que Arc System Works nos traiga Blazblue Chrono phantasma extend para steam (HYPE)

17065553.review:
This game is one of the greatest ( if not the)  greatest series of anime fighters there is.

Pros:
o Great singleplayer with amazing storymode.
o Very easy to learn with great tutorials for each character and easy to learn combos for every character.
o Challenges which teach you the characters moves and shows you combos for the character. 
o Very balanced, every character can shine and are of similar strengths. 
o Well written characters that are very different and sometimes relatable. 
o You can switch between announcers and you can switch between Japanese or English voices.

Cons: 
o Not the latest game in the series.
o Online is a bit hard to find, since this game is outdated.
o A bit pricy for an old game 
o Port is good but with very hard to configure controls. 

I reccomend this game to veterans or newcomers of anime fighters or fighting games in general. Big thumbs up!

Awesome 2d fighting game that can run 60fps on my low spec rig. It could be difficult at first, but once u learn the basic and headed to challenge mode you will be fine in no time. They also have stylish mode for beginer or if u just want to smash button for fun. 

The artwork is great, if you like anime styled character you will probably like the character. It also has decent story with ingame visual novel style (8/10 for story).
The netcode is working fine, but no1 play ranked match which is sad (where are you people??). People still play normal match though which is great.

The only problem I have is the display ratio, since the game doesn't allow me to adjust the ratio, I use my monitor scale ratio which is sometime work and sometime doesn't. But it is not game breaking.

Oh also good controller is very recommended for this game. Using keyboard is fine (not recommended) but of course a fine keyboard. Making a mistake is something you don't want in this game.

new note: They will release Blazblue Chronopantasm Extended soon. If u want to enjoy the story u have to buy at least BB continuum shift. Do it!! JUST DO IT!

16817948.review:
Well , what we got there ? Continum Shift Extend ? Wow , everybody believed it would never be released ,  and i have currently it in my library . As a great fan of the first game , BB Calamity Trigger , i will be quick on the pros of one of the greatest fighting game ever made :

Pros:
-a technical , and yet easy-to-learn gameplay . Lots of combos and strategies , but beginners won't be lost.

-BBCT lacked of characters  , but with this game you get the double of playable characters ! ( and each of them are unique and full of charisma : contrary to other mainstream fighting like Street Fighter , the fighters have personnalities and you can see it simply through their sprites and animation ! ( i particularly appreciate Hazama , the great evil of this sequel ^^ )

-A long , rich story mode , full of humor and serious plot ( but only if you love japanese anime like me ^^ )

-A bunch of contents , like CGs , videos , modes  and so on.

-Oh , and about the musics... They ROCK !! every character have their own ost , and some special ecounters (ex: Jin vs Ragna) have their unique battle theme . One of the best ost ever made for a fighting game ( but hey , ACS also made the Guilty Gears series , they know their job when it deals with making rock , metal epic themes )

-2d sprites are beautiful , the 3d backgrounds too and the design of the Blazblue world is somehow unique in its type

-And the best for the end : ONLINE MODE ! missing in the first game , network features come back in this sequel . And now that they fixed the early issues , it works perfectly.

Cons:

-The story is  complex and hard to understand , even though you played the first game ( but the story remains great ,and worth it )

-You must appreciate mangas / anime design ( i know not everybody appreciate it ... )

-Some bugs from times to times

- That's all !

Conclusion : CCCSE is an upgraded version of the first BB game : more characters , more features , online mode , solid gameplay...
The game worth it's 27,99 $
i will give it a honorable 9/10

Now let's just have fun fights while waiting for ChronoPhantasma Extend , the third and ultimate version of the BB series !

16413952.review:
[i]tl;dr further down, yo.[/i]

An excellent port of my favourite fighter! Mad props to the devs and publishers for finally releasing this gem on Steam. ♥

Each fighter utilizes distinct mechanics and play very differently from each other, which makes for an extremely complex yet very comprehenshible combat experience. For example, Iron Tager can [b]magnetize[/b] his opponents to draw them in close. Rachel Alucard deploys traps around the stage and brews up [b]wind[/b] to manipulate position and momentum. Platinum the Trinity cycles between a range of different weapons and Arakune aims to [b]curse[/b] his opponents in order to deal extra damage with a swarm of insects.

[i]BlazBlue: Continuum Shift[/i] also features a couple of game modes designed to teach players some proper mechanics, such as an extensive hands-on Tutorial and a demanding [b]Challenge Mode[/b] where you can train combos and learn all about each fighter's unique quirk and play style. Even though BlazBlue can be very demanding when it needs to, it is still fair toward new players, both to the game itself and to fighters in general.

Personally, the most pleasing aspects of the game lies in its gorgeous visuals and charming narrative. Though the story is your typical run-of-the-mill anime (science vs. religion, WW2-alluded cataclysms, obnoxious lolis, catgirls, scruffy men, technobabble etc. ad infinitum) the narrative truly shines in the BlazBlue's well developed characters. In the game's visual novel Story Mode, most of the fighters express striking personalities and quirks beyond their stereotyped exterior, and their relations to each other are reflected in almost every single aspect of the game.

Among the few peeves I've experienced is that some of the English voice actors are replaced in certain parts of the more recently recorded story/arcade dialogues. This, at least to me, breaks immersion quite a bit. A second issue is that the story can be unnecessarily convoluted and if you haven't played the first installment, [i]Calamity Trigger[/i], the plot can prove extremely confusing even though it's not very deep at all.

Another double-edged sword is the "Stylish" input mode, which allows inexperienced players to execute combos without effort. Though this can be convenient in Story Mode where you just want to blaze through the action with a character you've never played, it backfires miserably in Matchmaking when [strike]subhuman trash[/strike] rookies mess your heck up even though they haven't earned that skill. Even I, a lowly noob who cannot even manage a single proper combo (...), valiantly avoids using the Stylish mode for this very reason. How else could I properly improve?

The only thing missing with this game is YOU kicking filthy casuel ass (including me) in Matchmaking. In this writing moment, only 30 people are playing it! How can this beee!?

Now let's just wait for the [b]sequel[/b] to get a Steam release as well! ([i]Please[/i] don't forget Europe this time...!!)

[b]tl;dr[/b] : Fantastic mechanics, likable characters, killer soundtrack and plz release [i]Chronophantasma[/i] omg

16314611.review:
Considering my additional playtime and the fact that the game is on sale at the moment, it's about time i'd write an acctual "review"

Pro's:
+Good netcode.
+Long and very good story mode. (all characters have a story mode, combining for 3 seperate endings per character and then a final "True" ending)
+Very good, although lenghty, tutorial for newcomers
+Insanely good soundtrack which comes free with the game, for examples search for "Sword of Doom, "Active Angel" or even the main (astral finish) theme "Shinsou"
+All characters differ by an insane amount which is mostly due to the unique "Drive" attack each gets, from Rachel flying all over the stage to Valkenheyn's different stance to Platinum's weapon switching, they all differ alot and there aren't any exceptions on that.
+"Unlimited" characters, every character has a "Unlimited" mode which boosts their already existing abilities to a completely new level (the closest comparison would be SF4's "OMEGA" mode)


Cons:
-Silly losses in the story mode, sooner or later you have to fight someone that lore-wise is way stronger then the character you will be playing as, but this isen't notable in the slightest in the fight itsself so as a result you can get a perfect and then launch the enemy straight through a moon just to see your character get killed by the beforementioned enemy in the very next cutscene.
-The higher difficulty A.I loves being cheesy.
-Rather low playercount, this is easilly the biggest problem i have with BBCSE, i can find players rather quick (2to4ish minutes) but it's still noteworthy (for the playercount, http://steamcharts.com/app/294810, it's more then what it shows since it doesent take players into account with private profiles and the likes, but it's still not on the high side)

Summary:
Blazblue:CSE is, atleast for me, tied for my #1 fighting game (the other being Skullgirls) thanks to the amazing characters, gameplay systems in play and the amazing story 
As a result, I have absolutely no doubt in recommending it

PS:I play on my laptop with keyboard controls whenever i'm not at home, it's far from perfect and some characters are absolutely unplayable for me (Tager i.e.), but for the most part it get's the job done.

16268030.review:
I can't say enough of the BlazBlue series, the younger cousin to Guilty Gear.. Tight controls, intuitive mechanics, diverse selection of characters for many different playstyles. You've got your fast rushdowns, zoners, grapplers, puppets, and more. Every character is unique. Every character has a decent chance at winning against everyone else. The only one who seems to be at a disadvantage is Tager against good zoners and range. However, he is still deadly upclose and can quickly turn the tide. There are no clones here. The only exeption is Nu-13 and Lambda-11. However that doesn't really count as Nu-13 is only available as Lambdas unlimated form and isn't tourney legal. Moving on, the story in BB is surprisingly engaging for a fighter. Continuum Shift expands on the universe laid out by Calamity Trigger. Now, when I played CT, I was a little confused to what the actual fuck is going on, but CS cleared all of those questions up while, naturally, leaving its own wtf is going on moments for the next game to answer. Also, to those who skipped on CT, CS includes an abbreviated version of CT. My favorite parts of the story are th gag reels. My personal favorite gag scenes being for: Relius, Arakune, Tager, Bang, Noel, Valkenhayn, Rachel, and Ragna. As for my favorites to play: Jin, Tager, Hakumen, Nu-13/Lambda, Makoto, Litchi, and Hazama.

Now hurry up and give me my Chronophantasma! I need my Terumi fix!!!!! And Kagura looks awesome as hell!

Holy shit I put 40 hours into this game in two weeks. 
How does this happen I haven't even finished the story mode yet?
I'll tell you how. People actually still play online and the achievements and variety of challenges and game modes this game provides are great to complete.

Summary of this game:
Unfortunately not the lastest Blazblue pc port, a pretty decent port I have no problems with FPS (max 60) .
You can easily play with the person sitting beside you using the same keyboard (wasd and arrow keys).
This game is a great time waster now introducing more characters and modes in comparison to calamity trigger.
Modes available in the game are Challenge mode to challenge yourself to combos, story which is pretty self-explanatory, tutorial for the basics, arcade mode to enjoy each characters stories while enjoying the combat system, versus mode to fight against cpus or humans, unlimited mars to challenge yourself to the ultimate test of raging and masochism, abyss mode to travel through the depths of fighting endless waves of characters to make your character stronger, better, faster, gallery to buy things like artwork, replay theater to watch replays of online matches and such, and the network mode for online experiences with different people. There are story modes for all the playable characters in the games and extra chapters such as sector seven and the academy chapter to give more backstory on noel, tsubaki, makoto, tager, relius and kokonoe. I have yet to finish the story mode but there are a lot of replayable story modes to complete going through blazblue. 

Definite buy if the game goes on sale, lowest price is $14.99
Overall 9/10- Great experience, great time waster, enjoyed it and was well worth my money.
